text: in the coming weeks financial reporters
that the New York Times are going to be
presenting a series on the financial
crisis these stories are going to be
seen through the eyes of some of the
major players at some of the biggest
companies involved in the crisis it's a
way for us to explain to you how just a
few bad mortgages could have gotten the
American economy into this current state
the first story in the series is about
AIG american international group the
world's largest insurance company this
is a story of how a very solid well
capitalized immensely powerful company
was taken down by a tiny obscure unit of
people working in london called AIG
financial products this was a company a
unit that had 400 people or so out of a
hundred and sixteen thousand at AIG that
we're taking on some risky securities
and agreeing to insure them for their
clients what this illustrates is how a
aiji's unit took a very small tiny
sliver of risk and yet that little risk
almost blew up the entire company this
is something that it's very hard to
understand but I think is really so
crucial to our comprehension of where we
are today in the financial crisis and
the other stories in the series will
also examine how precisely we got into
this fix
